schema_place.name: Killington Peak
schema_place.description: Killington Peak is a 4,229 foot peak in Vermont offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Killington Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Killington Peak take 3-5 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 7.2 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Killington Peak hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Killington Peak is rated Hard. At 4,229 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Killington Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Killington Peak. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Killington Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Bucklin Trail, offering Most popular hiking route to Killington summit..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Killington Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Killington Peak is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,229 feet, Killington Peak ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footersa collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Bucklin Trail**, covers 7.2 miles and is rated Hard. Most popular hiking route to Killington summit.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Pico Peak lies just 3.4 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
